div.head: Standards: what are they good for?

list.item: hermeneutics
disambiguation
syntax and semantics

div.head: Standards and scholarship
div.p:
In the scholarly and scientific world we can distinguish
standards derived from community-specific needs
standards consequent on the use of particular technologies
standards imposed by external factors (funding, social context, habit...)

div.head: Can we do without standards?
div.p:
Standards often seem like an unnecessary nuisance :
the risks of premature fossilization
inventing a standard is time consuming and requires a change of perspective
conformance to a standard we didn't invent can be something we'd rather defer
But ....

div.head: Standards are really, really useful!
div.p: Standards help us

list.item: identify and locate relevant resources on the web or elsewhere
test and evaluate work done by other researchers
enrich existing resources with our own perspectives
distinguish resources from the tools that manage or mediate them

div.head: Standards improve our technical competences !
div.p:
Standards help developers
recombine and reuse existing system components
design and implement software in a modular fashion
reduce training costs
re-apply generic solutions in many different domains
There are many FAQs!

div.head: A quixotic goal/big claim
div.p: From the very beginning, the TEI has concerned itself with Guidelines about the construction, the description, the organization, and the annotation of digital corpora, both literary and linguistic
Texts of every kind, from every period, in every language

div.head: A question that has to be asked

list.item: The TEI is really old (born in 1987) !
Older than the Web, the DVD, the mobile phone, cable television, Microsoft Word..
Technologies that list more than five years old are quite rare

item.hi: Why and how has the TEI survived more than 30 years?

div.p: How should a standard evolve?

div.head: Scholarly communities
div.p:
Historically speaking, the TEI came about as the result of an unusual coincidence of interests amongst..
literary scholars interested in stylistics, genre theorists, devotees of close reading ...
linguists, in particular corpus linguists
textual editors
historians and archivists
librarians and bibliographers
computer scientists ...
The 1980s saw the begining of the digital turn: the conversion of written and spoken texts to digital form on a grand scale.

div.head: Consequently
div.p: ... along with a perceived risk of a new confusion of tongues consequent on that turn.

div.head: Interdisciplinarity
div.p: The TEI was probably one of the first great interdisciplinary efforts of its period. The members of its committees were drawn from many different academic specialisms, having in common only an interest in the digital turn.

This goes some way to explain two of its more striking architectural characteristics –
the widespread application of Ockham's razor
the insistence on customizability

div.head: Other oppositions
div.p:
Then as now, the TEI (and indeed the digital humanities) needed to negotiate two contradictions:
the needs of beginners and the needs of experts
the needs of scholars and the needs of technicians

list.item: On the one hand, the TEI should document the consensus topics on which every one knows the right answer -- of which beginners are therefore required to be aware
On the other, the TEI should support research, and hence permit the discovery of solutions to questions not yet asked or askable -- thus allowing experts to share their expertise .
On the one hand, the TEI offers the technician well-developed widely-tested solutions, easily implemented with current technologies
On the other, the TEI formal model is expressed in a way that is accessible to the non-technician, and derives from a set of concepts familiar to those with knowledge of the human sciences

div.head: Imperialism
div.p:
Despite its name, the TEI is not concerned only with textual data. Even in its first version, it proposed markup for
bibliographic metadata
oral transcriptions
abstract linguistic (or other) analyses e.g. using feature structures as well as markup for the traditional organization of books and of their typical components

div.head: In the beginning...
div.p:
Originally, the TEI had nothing to say about …
the web (it didn't exist yet)
layout and formatting(tex, scribe…)
digital facsimiles combining page image and transcription
representation of facts, objects, events (database country)
software in general
The TEI focus was on metadata, text, and its analysis, in a linguistic and literary paradigm...
Nous avons changé tout cela

div.head: Today's TEI supports all kinds of intelligent markup
div.p:
It is applicable to the encoding of ...
structural and functional components of a text
diplomatic transcription of historical sources, images, and their annotation
all manner of links, correspondences, alignments amongst documentary components
data and named entities: for example temporal expressions, names of people, places, and events, and the entities they references
peritextual and metatextual annotation(correction, suppression, additions); genetic and documentary editing
linguistic analyses
all kinds of metadata
... formal definitions of markup schemes!
selection is everything

list.item: Fundamentally identical objects often have different names in different contexts or disciplines and (slightly less often) fundamentally different objects have the same name

To avoid an unmanageable multiplication of concepts, the TEI often provides
a generic concept rather than a specific one (eg div, q)
and only occasionally some subtly distinct variations(eg said, quote, mentioned... )

div.head: Customization
div.p: The TEI provides a framework -- a kind of lego kit -- for the construction of an encoding scheme adapted to individual user needs, but which remains understandable by other people or systems, and within which any modification can readily be identified and understood.

div.head: There is no such thing as THE “TEI dtd”

list.item: The TEI is a modular system. You use it to create a personalised encoding system by choosing components, such as modules, and combining them
A module is a predefined collection of element and attribute declarations
You can select the elements you want, and change some of their properties
You can add new elements, defined by you, or taken from other standards

div.head: TEI modules (1)
div.p: You will almost certainly need some of these:

row.cell: basic features common to almost every kind of document
datatypes, classes, and macros used by every TEI module

div.head: TEI Modules (2)
div.p: If you are marking up specific documents (e.g. manuscripts) rather than generic texts you will need some of these:

row.cell: manuscript and incunabula cataloguing and description
diplomatic or genetic transcription of primary sources

div.head: The TEI Guidelines
div.p: In their 1 400 printed pages you will find :

list.item: a lexicon of 569 elements

item.label: rules and constraints on their usage

list.item: expressed informally in natural language
expressed in a TEI XML vocabulary (ODD) which can be mapped to other formal languages (DTD, W3C Schema, RELAXNG Schematron...)
lots of discussion notably including many usage examples

div.p: http://www.tei-c.org/Guidelines

list.item: A new version of TEI P5 appears approximately twice a year, usually containing corrected errors, new examples, clearer documentation etc. But new features also appear...

The Birnbaum Doctrine requires that existing features should be retained (unless they are really broken): a document conformant with the first release of P5, should remain conformant with all subsequent versions

When an existing feature is changed or withdrawn, it must go through a process of deprecation, lasting 6 months to a year, during which its imminent demise will be signalled explicitly by any TEI processor.

div.head: Why should you still care about the TEI ?
div.p:
There are probably two main reasons why standards fail :
they are based on a premature theory, insufficiently tested in the wild
they provoke a not invented here reaction: the potential user community is too divers or too fragmented
The secret of the TEI's successful longevity may lie in its adaptability

div.head: How do you ripen a theory ?
div.p:
A TEI customization can :
make a specific subset of existing TEI elements and attributes
add constraints limiting e.g. the possible values of attributes
add constraints on element content or co-occurrence, e.g. with ISO Schematron
add new elements or classes of elements within a non-TEI namespace, integrating them within predefined TEI model classes
This makes it easy to develop and test a proposed modification within the TEI framework, remaining TEI conformant.

list.item: TEI P5 has extensive I18N features ...
TEI is an XML environment that accepts other name spaces (a wrapper may be needed)

Hence integration of other XML vocabularies is easy :
SVG for graphics
MathML for mathematics
DCMI for metadata
…
A TEI element definition can formally define its semantic equivalence with other ontologies using the equiv element
A TEI document can contain non-TEI metadata, encapsulated within a xenoData element

div.head: Customization is not only a matter of selecting from the TEI cornucopia

list.item: additional constraints
definitionally true

div.head: Standards exist to be conformed to, right ?
The TEI ethos
div.p: What does it mean to "conform to the TEI" ?

list.item: agreed documented tagging praxis
respect for a shared lexicon of concepts
respect for encoding independence and autonomy

div.p: Standardisation does not mean « do what I do » ; it means « tell me what you have done in terms we both understand»

list.item: is a well formed XML document; and
is valid against one or more schemas, which may be either a TEI subset or a TEI extension; and
uses elements from the TEI namespace as defined by the TEI Guidelines; and
fully documents its use of the TEI by means of a TEI-conformant ODD vel sim.
honesty is the best policy
explicitness

div.head: Darwinian evolution works …

list.item: make your own modifications of the TEI using your own name space
document them properly in an ODD
discuss your proposals on TEI-L, or in a SIG !
make a "feature request" if you have identified a real gap in the TEI system
propose corrections as necessary
There are new versions of TEI P5 twice a year …

div.p: ... and don't forget to become a paid-up member of the Consortium !
